content.description: For a population of leghorn chickens, the mean number of eggs laid per chicken is 0.70 with standard deviation 0.20 egg. For a population of Sussex chickens, the mean number of eggs laid per chicken is 0.50 with standard deviation 0.10 egg. Two independent random samples of chickens were taken from the populations. The following table shows the sample statistics.
content.question: <math alttext="n" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>n</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="x bar" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mover><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>¯</mo></mrow></mover></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>s</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> Leghorn 36 0.75 0.30 Sussex 36 0.45 0.12 Mike claims that for all samples of size 36 from the population of leghorn chickens and all samples of size 36 from the population of Sussex chickens, the mean of all possible differences in sample means (leghorn minus Sussex) is 0.30 eggs per chicken. Is Mike’s claim correct?

choices.label: Yes. The mean is <math alttext="0.75 minus 0.45 equals 0.30" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.75</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.45</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0.30</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> egg per chicken.

No. The mean is <math alttext="0.30 minus 0.12 equals 0.18" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.30</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.12</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0.18</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> egg per chicken.

No. The mean is <math alttext="0.70 minus 0.50 equals 0.20 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.70</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.50</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0.20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> egg per chicken.

No. The mean is <math alttext="0.20 minus 0.10 equals 0.10" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.20</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.10</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0.10</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> egg per chicken.

No. The mean is <math alttext="36 times 0.75, minus 36 times 0.45, equals 10.8" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>36</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>0.75</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>−</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>(</mo><mn>0.45</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>10.8</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> eggs per chicken.

content.answer: No. The mean is <math alttext="0.70 minus 0.50 equals 0.20 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.70</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.50</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0.20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> egg per chicken.
